awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Development of a lighted infusion line to optimize care and decrease complications of critically ill patients in infectious isolation (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is to make the intensive care unit (ICU) safer for patients and less burdensome for nurses through the development of an illuminated intravenous tubes (IVT) for easier and error-free delivery of medications, enabling better care generally as well as during the COVID-19 pandemic. IVT identification requires an inordinate amount of nurses’ time and confers an immense cognitive burden as it requires manual tracing of the line from pump to patient. The errors associated with manual IVT tracing are costly, contributing to increased ICU length of stay and hospital liability. The current pandemic has exacerbated these issues as ICU admissions are rising and the use of enhanced isolation requiring extended IVT. Successful completion of the proposed program will support the development of an extended illuminated IVT that allows for reliable identification of IVT from pump to patient through the use of a fiber optic cable that nurses can turn on and off as needed when identifying lines. In comparison to the manual tracing of lines, an illuminated line has the potential to provide more rapid and error-free identification of IVT lines, thus reducing the impact of errors on patients, decreasing associated medical costs, and improving nurse workload.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I Project will advance the development of a novel lighted intravenous tubing (IVT) device to allow nurses to quickly and accurately identify IVT through the use of a light-emitting fiber optic cable attached to the outer wall of the IVT. Management of IVT and medication delivery, requires nurses to manually trace lines from pump to patient, which is an error prone process and particular interest for ICU patients that require upwards of 10 or more IVT lines simultaneously. The proposed program will advance the development of the extended illuminated IVT through the execution of two objectives. The first objective is to engineer the device to ensure that illumination can be maintained over the length of an extended line used in isolation settings. The second objective is to assess the performance of the extended prototype in a simulated ICU setting with enhanced isolation. Successful completion of the Phase I program will demonstrate feasibility of the extended illuminated IVT device in an isolation critical care setting as defined by reduced nurse burden and time in motion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview of Study : On November 15th, 16th, 17th, 2022, we consented and enrolled 15 Emory critical care nurses in the NSF Lightengale study. Nurses were then randomized to first complete the standard IV tubing or Lightengale line simulations. 

A. PreBrief: set the stage for each scenario, so that participants have success in achieving the research objectives. During the prebrief, we overviewed the scenario with each participant to ensure the registered nurses enrolled understood each part of the simulation.

B. Simulation: All participants engaged in two high-fidelity SBT scenarios with the same embedded clinical event requiring three different tasks. We created a sepsis scenario requiring the nurse to trace lines, provide a fluid bolus and hand a new IV bag and tubing to address the drop in blood pressure. High-fidelity simulation was utilized. Scenarios were delivered and facilitated by a team of simulation nurse educators at Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta Simulation Center. To understand nurse workload capacity comparing standard extended IVT versus extended Lightengale IVT, we randomized the scenarios and IVT. Each room is designed as an isolation adult ICU with blood pressure, end-tidal carbon dioxide tracing, oxygen saturation and electrocardiogram displayed via monitor in accordance with a realistic clinical scenario, with up-to-date technologies and equipped with standard equipment. Each high-fidelity manikin simulated complex pathologies and responds to medical and nursing interventions with realism. Basic vital signs and physiologic data including central venous pressure, arterial pressure, heart and respiratory rate are all available, along with appropriate PPE.

Each SBT had oversight/providing orders for each step of care by a critical care intensivist, acute care nurse practitioners, and the PI. Participants interacted with each sim patient as they worked through each scenario utilizing standard IVT or Lightengale IVT, in randomized order. Each scenario was audio-video recorded as standard procedure during SBT.

C. Debrief: Audio recording occurred during debrief where the PI met with each participant; at that time each scenario was reviewed and participants were asked their perception of Lightengale and functionality in their work setting.

Measure*

Standard

Mean (SD)

Lightengale

Mean (SD)

Paired Difference

(95% CI)

P-Value (ES1)

Lightengale  N=15

 

 

 

 

Unweighted

 

 

 

 

Mental Demand

57.73 (30.48)

40.13 (22.59)

-18.60 (-37.24, 0.04)

0.050 (0.66)

Physical Demand

43.80 (26.04)

31.47 (23.13)

-12.33 (-30.75, 6.09)

0.181 (0.49)

Temporal Demand

68.33 (25.50)

49.87 (28.05)

-18.47 (-38.51, 1.58)

0.070 (0.66)

Performance Rating

43.33 (29.60)

32.27 (31.23)

-11.07 (-31.45, 9.32)

0.264 (0.36)

Effort Rating

57.20 (28.71)

33.60 (19.65)

-23.60 (-42.00, -5.20)

0.014 (0.87)

Frustration Rating

61.13 (25.36)

25.53 (25.62)

-35.60 (-54.67, -16.53)

0.001 (1.15)

Weighted Mean Total

55.42 (22.28)

35.48 (21.04)

-19.94 (-36.15, -3.74)

0.018 (0.85)

*Sub-domains include participant scores of 0

Time-in-Motion early data analysis demonstrates an overall average difference between Lightengale IV tubing and standard IV tubing (tracing: 2:14 vs 2:27 minutes/seconds; bolus: 0.11 vs 0.27 seconds; 0.36 vs 0.52; respectively). This data is analysis before final confirmation.  Despite the minimal differences between the time-in-motion data, what is most striking is that nurses perceive there is a difference in their workload; with mental demand, time of the tasks, effort to complete IV tubing tasks and overall frustration level with tasks expected with line tasks. Ongoing analysis of the time-in-motion data will be complete for publication by August 2023. Additional regression analysis of time-in-motion and NASA-TLX will be finalized in next two weeks with manuscript submission.

Qualitative thematic analysis of the debrief data included the following themes: 1. Ease of use.  Participants discussed multiple times throughout the debrief interviews how “this could change so much with line tracing” , “so easy to see where the line was without much effort”; three of the participants who attend  the CRNA program said immediately “this would make work in the OR so much easier in trying to quickly find lines under the OR sheet to check sites, change medications etc” . 2. Decrease medication errors: Participants stated “…if I had this as a new nurse I think it would have helped me not to worry about medication errors”. Another participant stated “…. Are you going to study it in the hospital? Look at med error rate-this will decrease medication errors”.3. Confidence with Lines:.. “I would feel so much more confident at the beginning of the shift where my lines are…”.

Discussion: Despite the small sample size, we have demonstrated proof of concept, as nurses in this study perceived the lighted IV line would decrease work burden in a fast paced intense critical care unit. It has been well established, especially in time of historic nursing shortages that frustration, workload burden and mental exhaustion have contributed to nurse burnout, with over one million nurses projected to leave the profession by 2030. Our goal should be to improve the system and environment leading to nursing frustration and burnout. Lightengale clearly can be part of the solution.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2023
Modified by: Hans Utz
